comments.commentBody:
This is standard text, the same message Republicans have been droning on about for years. Having published this, the NYT won't need to publish any more, because they'll all be the same as this.

(Synopsis: More mouthwash with every statement, on every subject, every day. Always the same simple-minded message to the same simple-minded if dedicated hypocritical Flintstones outtakes claiming to be making America great again. Do you guys ever admit you're wrong about anything? Do you ever know when you're wrong? Has it occurred to you that there might be something wrong with being wrong? No, of course not. That'd involve some sort of intellectual process, and thinking is socialism, right?)

NYT readers please note a standard conservative "literary device" in this article. Like all good GOP fact-free products, it includes references to how liberals think, act and conduct themselves. Apparently "conservative" readers are OK with never sourcing any information from other sources, so they have to be told what liberals think, act, do, etc.

What is this, Grade School for the Grotesque? Most of the red states are economic disaster areas, social hellholes, and depressed for years, if not decades. Running America like the ALEC-murdered red states will simply raise the deficit, mis-prioritize spending, and create endless outlay and enforcement issues for the "downsized" government. Bookmark this article, folks, and watch it and every facile squeak in it die.

There'd still be public TV, that's something that would be produced by the liberal areas. What  are conservatives going to do, order the cable and broadcast TV to drop PBS in red states? Sure they'd get redder, like communist China, but would people tolerate it?

Rich,
Of course the "states rights" strategy doesn't work.

My question to you is why did it take three paragraphs to say basically, "historically speaking, that has never worked."

Compromise between sincerely principled persons is why this Country has succeed and prospered. But compromise requires a respect for your adversary.

Your side has tried very hard of recent times, to discrete "compromise". Why?

That would be a worthy topic for three paragraphs of thought.

Yes, Scott. Why listen to your constituents? You were elected to rule with an iron fist. And you are correct: the Confederacy fought the Civil War in the name of state's rights to turn the clock of history backward. And they won!
One question: what of blue states, who contribute disproportionately to the federal government through their income taxes? And what of those red states who enjoy disproportionate representation in the Senate and in the Electoral College? If you want to turn things back to the states? shouldn't abolition of the senate (think of the savings!!!) and of the electoral college be part of your formula?
what a dope.   I get the usefulness of all points of views, but do we really need to see him blather on.

Thanks to the NYT for allowing Scott Walker to reveal exactly what the Republican governing strategy is: do what they please without regard for truth, honor country and laws. Even pathetic characters like him must be allowed to exercise their freedom of speech.

After their derisive scorched earth policies enrage the public at large.
Mr Walker proposes ignoring them.
Let them eat cake, right?
Government by the people, for the people except when it goes against the Republican agenda. These people are so duplicitous.
States exist only to perpetuate unequal protection of law.

I want to thank The NYT for printing this contribution from Governor Walker. I almost scrolled past it but decided to give it a read. I feel it is time for all to break out of our insular bubbles to hear what those with opposing views to ours have to say (as repugnant as those views may be). Knowing the opponent and what their arguments are is the beginning of knowing how to counter punch with clear, concise and correct arguments to bring the facts to their attention and hopefully make the opponent stop a moment and at least consider what you're trying to impart. I hope the Times prints more of these viewpoints that make me see all arguments.

Walker and his ilk might consider listening to those protesters for a change rather then "standing strong" - whatever that means.  Wisconsin is lagging behind it's neighbors Minnesota and Iowa in most key measurements and continues to fade fast.

So basically the constitution, and will of the people doesn't matter to Right Wing Republicans like Scott Walker.  They can use their states as laboratories of authoritarian paternalism while keeping wages down and their citizens impoverished but freedom will ring throughout. Always remember Scott, Party and big business interests before country
Try listening to the protesters; they are often right. The arrogance of the right is becoming scary these days.

Dear Scott,
Your state supreme Court just repudiated your tax cut policies insofar as you are no longer able to adequately fund your public schools sufficiently to properly educate your children. So stand strong for the privilege of the rich parents in your state who can supplement their children's education. Those poor black and hispanic children don't deserve to be educated and they don't need a high school diploma to work in the prisons you have built for them,
Sincerely,
ABigFan

I notice Mr. Walker didn't mention in his "profiles of courage" governor Sam Brownback and his tax slashing experiment that has crippled Kansas.

He also fails to mention in his little right wing pep talk the specific issue those protestors are upset about. He and his gop brethren must stand strong in the face of these concerned constituents and take away their basic affordable healthcare! Go team!
Are they drug testing Walker and the rest of the state employees as well?  Taxpayer money goes to them as well.

This sack of filth cares nothing for the health of Wisconsin's citizens, as evidenced by his refusal to accept the Medicaid expansion part of the ACA. This crap about prefering to have local people care for the sick over "Wasington" is a false dichotomy, at best. Who was caring for the 20,000,000 Americans who weren't covered by health insurance before the ACA?

Walker and his filthy ilk care only for the wealthy, because he craves power. He advises his fellow filth to ignore people, as he does. The only good thing abour Walker is he's proven he doesn't have what it takes to become a serious presidential contender.

If we want to have dialog, respect, and effective policy development across party lines, cartoonish pronouncements like these are going to have to end.

Walker cites the usual boogeymen - welfare cheats (who are also dope fiends), whiny liberals, the ACA, and big government.

He offers no clear policy proposals and the claim of a mandate ("the clear answer in 2016") when less than 50% of voters went for the embattled President Trump is bizarre.

As far as policy being effected at the state level. I note that the most economically successful states are blue.

What a morning, The Pope calls for unselfish nonjudgemental charity. Governor Walker calls for testing and judging to be considered for charity. Hmm tough choice. I hope the Pope's advice is taken, the repugs will probably trash any safety net this 61 year old self employed carpenter may need in a few years.

Another way of saying this is the process of separating wheat from chaff is dubious when your partner in dialogue is doing everything possible to ensure the chaff remains mixed with the wheat, and is considered of higher value for their purposes.

You completely overrate Gov. Walker’s motives. He has no desire to “control” Trump; he is supports him in every way.

Walker throws in a bit about threats from protesters when he has no clue where the threats came from, when the fact is that 99.99% of the protests were absolutely peaceful and even respectful of corner-protestors. I was there, and I have video. Walker’s racism and codespeak is so glaring it hardly merits mentioning, but since when is being poor equivalent to being on drugs?
Since Trump lies so much why do we care what he says? Or tweets? The danger is that we will be worn down and stop paying attention to what he or Congress does.

Amy,
The way you describe your husband could have been written by me. My DH died several years ago, and he was one of a kind. I often commented that "The mold was "broken" when he was made."
I still miss him almost 15 years later. Being Chronically ill myself doesn't help matters. I remarried, stupidly thinking I might get lucky the 2nd time around....NOT. While I realize there's wonderful men out there, the very idea of "trying" once again, certainly makes me think twice about trying, although one wonders WHY I stay in a marriage like this I suppose.
The reason why I stay is due to being chronically ill, although I know better, I really do. I wish I could find someone like your Jason, for I had someone like him once.
I remember when I was 15 and anticipating becoming 16 yrs old and able to date. One day my oldest sister ( she was 6 yrs older ) and I were talking and she asked me what my "dream guy " would be. When I described him, little did I know that I was describing the man I would marry shortly before my 20 th birthday ! My sister laughed and said " Sweetie" you and dreaming. IF guys like that really exsist, get me one too !!!
Well, after I married him, my sister told me that I indeed did marry what I dreamed about. She was so happy for me.
Our marriage was perfect....and I know people who are reading this are "rolling " their eyes, but it's true. We were married for 28.5 years and we never ever fought or had a cross word between us.
I was truly happy.

Dear Amy,
I wish you more!!!
Last October I celebrated my 5 year (Ovarian) cancerversary. If I could give you some of my time I would.
May your path be gentle and full of love.
Dear carailk. May YOU live a long happy life. The last two lines of your post made me cry, just like Ms Rosenthal 's essay. This world needs more kind hearted souls like both you and AKR.

Everyone's different, but I wouldn't join a roomful of Democrats shouting down my Republican Congressman.  In the end, the Congressman gets the message that the Democrats are beyond reach, which probably steels his position against the ACA.  If he's hopelessly conservative, my time would be better spent registering voters.  And if he will engage, I'd talk to him respectfully so he knows that reasonable people think trashing the ACA is unacceptable.
